plant_concentrations.References: (1) Segawa R; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 59: 556-63 (1997)
plant_concentrations.Value: Hexazinone was detected in 20 of the 43 plants from an area treated with the pesticide. The concentrations from this area ranged from 0-10 ppm. Only 1 of the 46 plants outside the treatment area tested positive for hexazinone with a concentration of 0.5 ppm(1).

fish_seafood_concentrations.References: (1) National Water Quality Monitoring Council. Water Quality Data. Organics, Pesticides. Hexazinone. USGS/EPA/ACWI. Available from as of Mar 16, 2017: https://www.waterqualitydata.us/portal
fish_seafood_concentrations.Value: Water quality data compiled from the Retrieval (STORET) Data Warehouse report monitoring data from the Maine Department of Environmental Protection, tissue sample data for Sept 2009 to Nov 2009 indicates that hexazinone was not detected in the samples collected from the blue mussel (Mytilus edulis)(1).

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Miles CJ, Pfeuffer RJ; Arch Environ Contam Toxicol 32: 337-45 (1997). Available from, as of Mar 21, 2017: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/9175497?dopt=Abstract (2) Schafer RB et al; Env Sci Tech 45: 1665-1672 (2011)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SEDIMENT: Hexazinone was not detected in any of the 27 stations tested in the sediment of the canals of Southern Florida(1). A maximum concentration of 123 ug/kg was reported for hexazinone in 144 sediment samples collected from 24 sites over 5 months in the spring and summer months of 2008/2009 from streams and rivers located within 150 km of Melbourne, Victoria, Australia(2).

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) National Water Quality Monitoring Council. Water Quality Data. Organics, Pesticides. Hexazinone. USGS/EPA/ACWI. Available from as of Mar 20, 2017: https://www.waterqualitydata.us/portal
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SEDIMENT: Water quality data compiled from the Retrieval (STORET) Data Warehouse and the USGS National Water Information System (NWIS) reports sediment monitoring data for hexazinone. Select data from the 2006 to 2016 monitoring years follows(1).
sediment_soil_concentrations.Table: [{'Dates': 'Jan - Dec 2006', 'Detections': '0 of 45 samples', 'Concns': 'not detected', 'Monitoring Sites': 'National Park Service Water Resources Division, FL Dept. of Environmental Protection, USGS CA'}, {'Dates': 'Feb - Aug 2010', 'Detections': '0 of 27 samples', 'Concns': 'not detected', 'Monitoring Sites': 'USGS CA, GA, LA, OR, CO, ID'}, {'Dates': 'Jan - Oct 2016', 'Detections': '0 of 99 samples', 'Concns': 'not detected', 'Monitoring Sites': 'USGS California Water Science Center'}]

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Feng JC et al; J Environ Sci Hlth Part B Pest Food Contam Agric Wastes 27: 639-54 (1992)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SOIL: The spatial distribution of hexazinone was measured in forest soil for 2 yr following the aerial application of a granular formulation, Pronone 10G, in northern Alberta, Canada. Initial deposition rates of two hexazinone treatments averaged 2.3 and 4.1 kg/ha for each triplicated plot. One yr after application, residues of hexazinone averaged 0.25 and 0.40 kg/ha in 2.3 and 4.1 kg/ha treatment, respectively, in the 0-10 cm surface soil; and were distributed vertically in soil depths of 0-10 cm surface, 10-20 cm at rations of 10:11:2 and 10:5:2, respectively, in 2.3 and 4.1 kg/ha treatment. Two yr after application, the vertical movement of hexazinone in soil was quantifiable to 40 cm depth in both 2.3 and 4.1 kg/ha treatment plots. Trace amounts of hexazinone were detected at 130 cm only in the 2.3 kg/ha plot, which is likely due to the more freely downward movement of hexazinone to deeper horizons along decayed root channels(1).

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) National Water Quality Monitoring Council. Water Quality Data. Organics, Pesticides. Hexazinone. USGS/EPA/ACWI. Available from as of Mar 20, 2017: https://www.waterqualitydata.us/portal
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SOIL: Water quality data compiled from the USGS National Water Information System (NWIS) reports 2011 soil monitoring data for hexazinone from the USGS New Jersey Water Science Center indicating that hexazinone was not detected in suspended soil samples collected in Oct 2011 (LOD = 1.2 ug/kg )(1).

plant_translocations.content: Seedlings of winged elm (Ulmus data Michx.), bur oak (Quercus macrocarpa Michx.), black walnut (Juglans nigra L.), eastern redcedar (Juniperus virginiana L.), and loblolly pine (Pinus taeda L.) were subjected to treatment with ring-labeled 14C-tebuthiuron and 14C-hexazinone in a nutrient solution. After four hours, 14C was detected in all sections of winged elm treated with both 14C-tebuthiuron and 14C-hexazinone. The absorption of tebuthiuron label by the other species through the roots occurred in the following order: loblolly pine > bur oak > black walnut = eastern redcedar. Similarly, the absorption of hexazinone label followed the sequence: loblolly pine > black walnut > bur oak = eastern redcedar. Regarding foliar accumulation, the tebuthiuron label was found to accumulate in the following order: bur oak > loblolly pine > eastern redcedar = black walnut. On the other hand, the sequence for hexazinone accumulation was: loblolly pine > bur oak > black walnut = eastern redcedar. The presence of three metabolites of hexazinone in loblolly pine suggests that this species may exhibit resistance to hexazinone due to its ability to degrade the herbicide rather than its ability to limit uptake.
plant_translocations.reference: McNeil, W. K., Stritzke, J. F., & Basler, E. (1984). Absorption, translocation, and degradation of tebuthiuron and hexazinone in woody species. Weed Science, 32(6), 739-743.

method.Test Plant: Bur oak (Quercus macrocarpa), black walnut (Juglans nigra), eastern redcedar (Juniperus virginiana), loblolly pine (Pinus taeda)
method.Plant Grown Condition: 12- to 15-month-old seedlings obtained from the Oklahoma State Nursery
method.Chemical Preparation: Nutrient solution containing 30 µl of 14C-tebuthiuron (0.898 µCi) or 14C-hexazinone (0.40 µCi) in ethanol
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: Seedlings were transferred to fresh nutrient solution with labeled herbicide concentrations of 0.5 µM
method.Other Information: Experiment arranged as a split-plot design with two herbicides and two to three exposure-time intervals, replicated four to seven times. Herbicide degradation was determined using tissue remaining from the 4- and 24-h herbicide exposure times. Leaf and root tissues were pooled over replications for extraction and analysis.
